webTitle: Burger King withdraws Blige TV ad

fields.standfirst: Food chain acts after African-American groups accuse it of peddling stereotypes
fields.body:
Burger King has withdrawn a TV commercial featuring Mary J Blige promoting its new, healthier chicken snacks just days after it launched the biggest shakeup to its US menu since its founding in 1954.

The advert, which features the Grammy award-winner singing about Burger King's crispy chicken snack wraps, had been criticised by some African-American groups, who accused the chain of peddling stereotypes. Burger King said the advert, part of a major new healthier eating campaign, was pulled for licensing reasons and would be back on air soon. Other celebrities featuring in the chain's "Exciting things are happening at Burger King" ads include David Beckham, Jay Leno and Salma Hayek.

The company is launching 10 new items, including smoothies, frappe coffees and chicken strips, in its biggest ever menu expansion. "What consumers told us basically is, 'We love the Whopper … but you guys have to catch up in some important product categories specifically salads, smoothies and wraps'," Alex Macedo, Burger King's north American marketing director, told Ad Age.

webTitle: Eurozone fears revive to drag down markets

fields.bodyText: Shares in the City suffered their biggest fall in more than four months today as global financial markets were unnerved by a fresh flare-up in Europe's debt crisis and hints that America's central bank is reluctant to pump more cash into the world's biggest economy. Ignoring the upbeat UK economic news, London's benchmark FTSE 100 index took its cue from jittery European bourses and closed 134.57 points lower at 5703.8, a drop of 2.3%. In America, the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 124.80, a fall of just below 0.95%, at 13074.75. Markets had opened lower after the minutes of the US Federal Reserve's policy-making committee appeared to rule out a third bout of quantitative easing, the programme of bond purchases by the central bank that has twice before boosted the American money supply. The mood further darkened on news of a deepening slump in the eurozone's services sector, which was shortly followed by a disappointing bond auction in Spain. Amid growing concerns that the respite from the debt crisis provided over the past four months by the European Central Bank (ECB) is coming to an end, Spanish 10-year bond yields rose by more than 0.25 points to 5.7%, after the government in Madrid struggled to sell new issues of debt. Spain sold €2.6bn (£2.15bn) of bonds, at the low end of the government's target range and, to placate fears that it might eventually become the fourth eurozone country to require an international bailout, had to offer investors an interest rate of 5.338% on debt maturing in 2020. This was higher than the 5.2% forecast and the 5.156% offered when the debt was last sold in September 2011. Spanish economy minister Luis de Guindos admitted on Wednesday that the biggest risk facing the country was the belief that Madrid would not be able to bring down its budget deficit. In an interview with Reuters, de Guindos said Madrid was determined to reduce the budget deficit to 5.3% of national output in 2012 and to the European Union ceiling of 3% in 2013. "The main negative effect, the main risk for the Spanish economy, is the perception that public accounts are not sustainable … the 5.3% commitment is very important but the 3% commitment is very, very important," he said. The ECB kept its key interest rate unchanged at 1% on Wednesday, with the bank's president, Mario Draghi, publicly resisting German pressure to begin preparing an exit strategy from the emergency funding operations that have been used to support Europe's banks. Since the late autumn, the ECB has announced two long-term refinancing operations in an attempt to provide cheap credit for banks struggling to obtain credit, but the president of the German Bundesbank, Jens Weidmann, has expressed concerns that the "wall of money" released by Draghi will lead to higher inflation. After a survey showed the eurozone's services sector moving deeper into recession last month, Draghi said: "Given the present conditions of output and unemployment, which is at a historical high, any exit strategy, talking for the time being, is premature." He added bluntly: "I think the president of the ECB is the one who has the last word on this." Draghi said the bank had not discussed changing interest rates, although some analysts believe a double-dip recession in the eurozone will lead to lower borrowing costs later this year. Draghi also sought to reassure the Bundesbank that the ECB was not going soft on inflation. "All our non-standard policy measures are temporary in nature," he told the regular post-meeting news conference. "All the necessary tools are available to address upside risks to medium-term price stability in a firm and timely manner." This rise showed financial markets expected governments on the eurozone periphery to deliver reforms, Draghi said, putting pressure on those countries to shape up rather than looking to the ECB to act further. "Markets are asking these governments to deliver," he said. Following the falls in Europe, shares on Wall Street were down by 1% in morning trading, while the price of crude oil fell to $124 a barrel. The eurozone economy shrank 0.3% in the fourth quarter and indicators for future growth remained weak, raising the likelihood that the economy shrank again in the first quarter. Unemployment is at a record 10.8% for the 17 eurozone countries, while youth unemployment has reached unprecedented levels of 50% in Spain and Greece. Annual inflation of 2.6% remains stubbornly above its 2% target. The ECB blames higher oil prices rather than inflationary pressures from the economy.

webTitle: Kraft boss earns $22m after Cadbury's cuts

fields.standfirst: Irene Rosenfeld, the controversial boss of US food group Kraft, earned $22m last year after hitting targets tied to cutting costs
fields.body:
Irene Rosenfeld, the controversial boss of US food group Kraft, earned $22m last year after hitting targets tied to cutting costs at Cadbury. Rosenfeld's pay rose by 13.5% after she took home a performance-based bonus reflecting strong turnover growth as well as the savings made at Cadbury, which it acquired in a hostile takeover two years ago. The payout is likely to cause anger as 200 manufacturing jobs are being cut at the confectioner's historic base at Bournville.

Rosenfeld's annual performance-based bonus was $4.2m, nearly double the previous year's, after turnover at the snacks company rose 6.6%, beating the 4% target. The company said her bonus related to gaining market share, improving shareholder returns and delivering cost savings related to the Cadbury – which are now expected to exceed the original $750m envisaged – ahead of schedule.

webTitle: Former JJB boss Chris Ronnie accused over £1m fraud

fields.standfirst: Ex-chief executive appears at a London magistrates court charged with fraud, money laundering and 'furnishing false information'
fields.body:
Chris Ronnie, the colourful former chief executive of JJB Sports, has been charged with a series of offences relating to an alleged £1m fraud, following an investigation by the Serious Fraud Office.

Ronnie, 50, who ran the sportswear chain between August 2007 and March 2009, appeared at Westminster magistrates court on Wednesday charged with three fraud offences as well as two counts of money laundering and two of "furnishing false information".

David Ball, the co-owner of JJB supplier Fashion & Sport, was charged with three counts of furnishing false information.

Both defendants were released on unconditional bail.

The SFO said the alleged fraud related to a "failure to disclose interests in contracts" entered into by the firm in 2008.

The court action is the first to surface since JJB executives set the hare running in 2009, calling in the Office of Fair Trading – in exchange for immunity – to investigate the possibility that it had fixed prices with rival Sports Direct, the sportswear firm run by Newcastle United owner Mike Ashley, when Ronnie was at the helm. Ronnie previously worked at Sports Direct.

Sports Direct is the UK's biggest sportswear retailer and both chains enjoy strong positions in the market for replica football shirts. The OFT asked for the assistance of the SFO and it later emerged that the investigation had widened to suspected fraud. But to date the high-profile inquiries, which rocked the close knit sportswear industry, have come to nothing.

In 2010 the SFO said its investigation into Sports Direct and JJB Sports had been completed and no charges would be brought. Then last year the OFT threw in the towel on its price-fixing inquiry as it had uncovered "only limited evidence of potential price-fixing, much of which is contradicted by other material" and had other higher priority investigations to pursue.

"JJB has cooperated fully with the SFO in relation to its investigation," a JJB spokesman said .

The SFO said "investigations into possible offences committed by other suspects are ongoing". The identity of other suspects is not known and last year Sports Direct said that "no individuals" connected to the firm were being investigated.

Ronnie's lawyer Anthony Barnfather said: "Mr Ronnie has fully co-operated with the Serious Fraud Office investigation and is surprised and disappointed at the decision. He strenuously denies the charges, has always maintained his innocence and is confident his position will be vindicated in due course."

JJB has struggled to recover from Ronnie's tenure, narrowly avoiding administration thanks to a series of cash calls to investors, who include Microsoft founder Bill Gates.

Its low share price was boosted this week after it confirmed it was in talks with its lender and one of its strategic partners about raising additional financing. They closed up 0.25p at 16.25p.

webTitle: Tycoon's move flips Burger King back on the market

fields.standfirst: Nicolas Berggruen and business partner Bill Ackman said that their London-listed Justice Holdings had agreed to buy the minority stake in the world's second-biggest burger chain
fields.body:
A hedge fund tycoon known as the "homeless billionaire" is part of a team of well-known businessmen who have launched a $1.4bn (£800m) takeover of a 29% stake in Burger King.

Nicolas Berggruen – given his nickname because he travels between the world's most luxurious hotels aboard his private Gulfstream IV jet – and business partner Bill Ackman, a multi-billionaire activist investor, announced that their London-listed investment vehicle Justice Holdings had agreed to buy the minority stake in a deal that will see the world's second-biggest burger chain return to the stock market.

Berggruen, who started out with a $250,000 trust fund and is now worth more than $2.3bn, said he selected Burger King because it "stood out as a unique global player" with a "strong heritage".

The son of a successful art collector who was a close friend of Picasso, Berggruen was expelled from a Swiss boarding school before moving to New York and building up a property empire in the now über-fashionable West Village. He co-founded a group of hedge funds before he was 27.

Berggruen, 50, hosts an annual celebrity-drenched party at Hollywood's Chateau Marmont on the night before the Oscars. Guests have included Leonardo DiCaprio and Paris Hilton.

Justice, founded by Berggruen; Ackman, chief executive of Pershing Square Capital; and Martin Franklin, the British-born chairman of US consumer goods group Jarden Corporation, agreed to buy a 29% stake in Burger King from 3G Capital, an investment fund backed by Brazilian beer billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann, Marcel Telles and Carlos Alberto Sicupira.

Lemann, a former tennis player and Brazil's fourth richest man with a net worth of $12bn, and his 3G partners will retain a 71% stake. Burger King will return to the New York stock exchange shortly.

Ackman and his family will own 10% of the company, Berggruen and Franklin about 2% each, with the remaining 15% as a free float.

Justice, formed last year, is chaired by Lord Myners, the former City minister. It has ceased trading in London. Myners described Burger King as "extremely attractive" and said the deal "stood head and shoulders above" all other possible Justice targets.

Justice's board is studded with renowned figures including Nouriel Roubini, the economist who earned the nickname Dr Doom for his prediction of the financial crisis that hit in 2008, and Alan Parker, former chief executive of British hotels and restaurants chain Whitbread.

Franklin and Parker will join Burger King's board.

Daniel Schwartz, Burger King's finance director, said it was the "right time for Burger King to be publicly traded in the US again" following its delisting in 2010 after 3G's acquisition. He said the deal gave Burger King an enterprise value of $8bn, almost double the amount 3G paid.

Burger King serves more than 11m customers a day from 12,500 locations worldwide. About 90% of its restaurants are owned and operated by independent franchisees. The company, which traces its roots back to 1954, a year before the incorporation of McDonald's, made total revenue of $580.6m last year compared to McDonald's $27bn.

webTitle: Fiat boss hailed by US for resurrecting Chrysler stalls in Europe as sales fall

fields.standfirst: Sergio Marchionne's legacy dented by effects of Europe's austerity drive and Fiat's inability make mark in new markets
fields.body:
Sergio Marchionne, the man who turned Fiat around and was then invited by President Obama to do the same for Chrysler, was beamed into millions of American homes in March, when CBS's 60 Minutes paid homage to his automotive miracle.

"The people I was watching with were enchanted by him, he seemed intense and approachable, like a creative type out of Hollywood," said Rebecca Lindland, a US-based automotive analyst at IHS Global Insight.

Marchionne, now chief executive of Fiat and Chrysler, has become America's darling since taking Obama's bailout loans for the US car industry in 2009 and saving Chrysler – in which Fiat has taken a controlling 58% stake. Last year Chrysler boosted sales by 24% and paid back the $7.6bn (£4.85bn) loan six years ahead of schedule. This week it announced US March sale s up 34% – its best month for four years.

As if that were not enough, Marchionne declined to take any pay or bonus from Chrysler for 2011.

His next trick involves building Lancias and Maseratis in Detroit, as well as Jeeps in Russia and a new car in China based on Dodge and Alfa Romeo parentage.

But if the 59 year old has become a hero in the US, elsewhere his legacy is far from secure. Marchionne, who was born in Italy and raised in Canada, may have made Fiat more flexible in Italy, but shifting working hours around means little when a continent struck by austerity cuts is not buying cars.

Fiat domestic deliveries in March dropped to the lowest level in 32 years, the company revealed, as Italians face recession, higher taxes and rising gas prices. The European market as a whole is expected to contract for the fifth year in a row, but Marchionne told shareholders Fiat's European business would break even by 2014.

Meanwhile in China, which for carmakers is the place to be, Fiat has so far stumbled in making alliances but watched rival German companies streak ahead.

"Fiat is risking trying to outrun the world and as a result may be spreading itself too thinly," said Ian Fletcher, a London-based analyst at IHS. "I will be surprised if Marchionne can make good on his promise to increase sales from four to six million cars by 2014."

Marchionne's appointment to run Fiat was decided at the 2004 funeral of Umberto Agnelli, the brother of Gianni Agnelli, who before his death in 2003 had turned Fiat into Italy's economic powerhouse.

The Agnelli family had bought Maserati, Ferrari, Alfa Romeo and Lancia and even invested in toll highways – the kind of Italian conflict of interest Silvio Berlusconi would later make a trademark.

By the time the old guard died off, many were predicting Fiat would follow suit. But then Marchionne arrived, promoted from a Fiat-owned Swiss company. His first tasks were to clean up the firm's accounts to avoid a bank takeover; close down the unproductive Termini Imerese line in Sicily; and promise to invest in other facilities if unions would allow more flexible working.

When the revamped Fiat 500 was launched to acclaim in 2007, Marchionne said he had rid the firm of "the smell of death".

Five years on, Marchionne has fully backed plans by Italian prime minister Mario Monti – who once sat on the Fiat board – to hand employers more powers to hire and fire, unsurprising given Marchionne's continued scrapping with unions over his flexibility drive.

The hard-smoking CEO carefully mixes his exasperation with Italy's high labour costs with union-pleasing talk of the "moral obligation" Fiat has to stay faithful to the country where it was founded.

There is no such need to tread carefully in the US. To consolidate Fiat's integration with Chrysler, the US maker launched the Dodge Dart this week, based on the Alfa Romeo Giulietta.

"We predict 95,000 sales by 2015, people are excited about this car," said analyst Rebecca Lindland.

Fiat's US production is meanwhile likely to rise to 100,000 in 2015, according to IHS, due to a new Maserati SUV being built in Detroit based on the body of a Jeep, which is a Chrysler brand, the return of the Alfa Romeo to the US market and the construction of Lancias for the EU market.

Chrysler's comeback helped boost Fiat's profits last year to €1.65bn (£1.37bn), but the firm lost €500m in Europe, where car sales show no sign of rebounding, and where Marchionne has demanded the EU oversee a 20% reduction in car manufacturing to cope with overcapacity.

Fiat is especially vulnerable to the very nasty downturn in Italy, where sales dropped 36% in March, thanks in part to a car transporters' strike, and production was down last year from 1.1m in 2007 to 650,000, less than the 800,000 cars the firm built in Brazil.

"Fiat may be trying to inject US-style flexibility in Italy, but flexibility needs peaks and there are no peaks right now," said Stefano Manzocchi, economics professor at Rome's LUISS university.

Analyst Ian Fletcher warned that Fiat was making a mistake by waiting for a turnaround to invest in new models. "They are pushing back the production of a new small SUV at the Mirafiori plant but that is the fastest growing sector in the EU – perhaps they can't afford it."

Analysts believe Marchionne must now commit Fiat and Chrysler to a full merger and also search out an Asian partner such as Mazda or Suzuki if he is to make up lost ground in Asia, where a series of tie-ups have collapsed. "Fiat is five to seven years behind the curve in China," said Fletcher, "while in India a deal to sell through Tata dealers didn't work and now they are going backwards there, not forwards like everyone else."

A new deal in China with Guangzhou Auto Group to open a plant by July to build 140,000 Fiat cars and 220,000 engines a year could reverse Fiat's fortunes there and has "an awful lot of potential", said Fletcher. The mishaps hitherto, he added, could be down to Fiat "taking its eye off the ball, under pressure to do too much".

Giuseppe Berta, an economist at Milan's Bocconi university, said that if Marchionne had proved his skills as a negotiator – with Italian unions and the Obama government – and as a cost cutter and an inspirational leader, he could struggle to oversee a global company in which delegation is key.

"Is Marchionne too individualistic for team management?" he asked. "And will he be able to form new partnerships without taking command?"

Style and drive

As NBC's 60 Minutes put it: "With his gray stubble, longish hair, relaxed demeanor and trademark black sweaters, Sergio Marchionne looks more like a film director than an auto executive, but he is now the industry's biggest star." But if the Americans were impressed by Marchionne's style, he is perhaps only following a Fiat tradition epitomised by the dominant force in the group's history, Giovanni Agnelli, below. Known as Gianni, the grandson of the carmaker's founder was famous for his dress sense and described by Life magazine in 1967 as "an exquisitely tailored Julius Caesar".

Chairman from 1966 to 1996, he had been notorious in the 1940s and 50s as a playboy, keeping houses in New York and St Moritz and was linked to a string of women including Anita Ekberg and Rita Hayworth. Milanese fashion designer Nino Cerruti named Agnelli as one of his biggest inspirations, alongside James Bond and John F Kennedy. But by the time Gianni died in 2003, Fiat was losing billions of euros. His younger brother Umberto, who took over as chairman, may have lacked his older brother's flamboyance but was perhaps the more successful businessman, despite his brief stint at the top.

Having earlier been in favour of selling the lossmaking car arm, once in the driving seat he performed a U-turn and sold off a range of other assets so Fiat could focus on vehicles.

"The people I was watching with were enchanted by him, he seemed intense and approachable, like a creative type out of Hollywood," said Rebecca Lindland, a US-based automotive analyst at IHS Global Insight. Marchionne, now chief executive of Fiat and Chrysler, has become America's darling since taking Obama's bailout loans for the US car industry in 2009 and saving Chrysler – in which Fiat has taken a controlling 58% stake. Last year Chrysler boosted sales by 24% and paid back the $7.6bn (£4.85bn) loan six years ahead of schedule. This week it announced US March sale s up 34% – its best month for four years. As if that were not enough, Marchionne declined to take any pay or bonus from Chrysler for 2011. His next trick involves building Lancias and Maseratis in Detroit, as well as Jeeps in Russia and a new car in China based on Dodge and Alfa Romeo parentage. But if the 59 year old has become a hero in the US, elsewhere his legacy is far from secure. Marchionne, who was born in Italy and raised in Canada, may have made Fiat more flexible in Italy, but shifting working hours around means little when a continent struck by austerity cuts is not buying cars. Fiat domestic deliveries in March dropped to the lowest level in 32 years, the company revealed, as Italians face recession, higher taxes and rising gas prices. The European market as a whole is expected to contract for the fifth year in a row, but Marchionne told shareholders Fiat's European business would break even by 2014. Meanwhile in China, which for carmakers is the place to be, Fiat has so far stumbled in making alliances but watched rival German companies streak ahead. "Fiat is risking trying to outrun the world and as a result may be spreading itself too thinly," said Ian Fletcher, a London-based analyst at IHS. "I will be surprised if Marchionne can make good on his promise to increase sales from four to six million cars by 2014." Marchionne's appointment to run Fiat was decided at the 2004 funeral of Umberto Agnelli, the brother of Gianni Agnelli, who before his death in 2003 had turned Fiat into Italy's economic powerhouse. The Agnelli family had bought Maserati, Ferrari, Alfa Romeo and Lancia and even invested in toll highways – the kind of Italian conflict of interest Silvio Berlusconi would later make a trademark. By the time the old guard died off, many were predicting Fiat would follow suit. But then Marchionne arrived, promoted from a Fiat-owned Swiss company. His first tasks were to clean up the firm's accounts to avoid a bank takeover; close down the unproductive Termini Imerese line in Sicily; and promise to invest in other facilities if unions would allow more flexible working. When the revamped Fiat 500 was launched to acclaim in 2007, Marchionne said he had rid the firm of "the smell of death". Five years on, Marchionne has fully backed plans by Italian prime minister Mario Monti – who once sat on the Fiat board – to hand employers more powers to hire and fire, unsurprising given Marchionne's continued scrapping with unions over his flexibility drive. The hard-smoking CEO carefully mixes his exasperation with Italy's high labour costs with union-pleasing talk of the "moral obligation" Fiat has to stay faithful to the country where it was founded. There is no such need to tread carefully in the US. To consolidate Fiat's integration with Chrysler, the US maker launched the Dodge Dart this week, based on the Alfa Romeo Giulietta. "We predict 95,000 sales by 2015, people are excited about this car," said analyst Rebecca Lindland. Fiat's US production is meanwhile likely to rise to 100,000 in 2015, according to IHS, due to a new Maserati SUV being built in Detroit based on the body of a Jeep, which is a Chrysler brand, the return of the Alfa Romeo to the US market and the construction of Lancias for the EU market. Chrysler's comeback helped boost Fiat's profits last year to €1.65bn (£1.37bn), but the firm lost €500m in Europe, where car sales show no sign of rebounding, and where Marchionne has demanded the EU oversee a 20% reduction in car manufacturing to cope with overcapacity. Fiat is especially vulnerable to the very nasty downturn in Italy, where sales dropped 36% in March, thanks in part to a car transporters' strike, and production was down last year from 1.1m in 2007 to 650,000, less than the 800,000 cars the firm built in Brazil. "Fiat may be trying to inject US-style flexibility in Italy, but flexibility needs peaks and there are no peaks right now," said Stefano Manzocchi, economics professor at Rome's LUISS university. Analyst Ian Fletcher warned that Fiat was making a mistake by waiting for a turnaround to invest in new models. "They are pushing back the production of a new small SUV at the Mirafiori plant but that is the fastest growing sector in the EU – perhaps they can't afford it." Analysts believe Marchionne must now commit Fiat and Chrysler to a full merger and also search out an Asian partner such as Mazda or Suzuki if he is to make up lost ground in Asia, where a series of tie-ups have collapsed. "Fiat is five to seven years behind the curve in China," said Fletcher, "while in India a deal to sell through Tata dealers didn't work and now they are going backwards there, not forwards like everyone else." A new deal in China with Guangzhou Auto Group to open a plant by July to build 140,000 Fiat cars and 220,000 engines a year could reverse Fiat's fortunes there and has "an awful lot of potential", said Fletcher. The mishaps hitherto, he added, could be down to Fiat "taking its eye off the ball, under pressure to do too much". Giuseppe Berta, an economist at Milan's Bocconi university, said that if Marchionne had proved his skills as a negotiator – with Italian unions and the Obama government – and as a cost cutter and an inspirational leader, he could struggle to oversee a global company in which delegation is key. "Is Marchionne too individualistic for team management?" he asked. "And will he be able to form new partnerships without taking command?" Style and drive As NBC's 60 Minutes put it: "With his gray stubble, longish hair, relaxed demeanor and trademark black sweaters, Sergio Marchionne looks more like a film director than an auto executive, but he is now the industry's biggest star." But if the Americans were impressed by Marchionne's style, he is perhaps only following a Fiat tradition epitomised by the dominant force in the group's history, Giovanni Agnelli, below. Known as Gianni, the grandson of the carmaker's founder was famous for his dress sense and described by Life magazine in 1967 as "an exquisitely tailored Julius Caesar". Chairman from 1966 to 1996, he had been notorious in the 1940s and 50s as a playboy, keeping houses in New York and St Moritz and was linked to a string of women including Anita Ekberg and Rita Hayworth. Milanese fashion designer Nino Cerruti named Agnelli as one of his biggest inspirations, alongside James Bond and John F Kennedy. But by the time Gianni died in 2003, Fiat was losing billions of euros. His younger brother Umberto, who took over as chairman, may have lacked his older brother's flamboyance but was perhaps the more successful businessman, despite his brief stint at the top. Having earlier been in favour of selling the lossmaking car arm, once in the driving seat he performed a U-turn and sold off a range of other assets so Fiat could focus on vehicles.

fields.trailText: Sergio Marchionne's legacy dented by effects of Europe's austerity drive and Fiat's inability make mark in new markets

webTitle: Tesco rebrands Value range

fields.bodyText: Tesco has ditched its blue-and-white striped Value label in favour of a new softer brand, as it tries to relieve consumers of the embarrassment of buying the cheapest products on its shelves. Rivals Asda and Sainsbury's have already given their "no frills" ranges a makeover and report strong growth as shoppers seek out bargains. The supermarket own-label budget market is growing at more than 9% a year, according to Kantar Worldpanel, with Tesco Value achieving annual sales of £1bn. Launched in the depths of the early 1990s recession, the Value brand was Tesco's answer to the baked bean price war triggered by the now defunct Kwik Save, which was selling 3p cans of beans and 7p loaves of bread. Tesco UK's marketing director, David Wood, said:"Tesco was the first supermarket to launch a Value range back in 1993, the blue-and-white striped brand giving customers a down-to-earth option. Almost 20 years on, affordable quality is more relevant than ever, but customer needs have changed. Everyday Value will provide products that taste better, look better and are healthier." The new label looks more upmarket, with colourful packaging featuring 1950s-style line drawings of kitchen equipment and food. Tesco has revamped some of the 550 products in the range, taking out MSG and hydrogenated fats, and promises they will taste better with the lemon curd "more lemony" and 33% more apple in the apple sauce. Tesco's chief executive, Philip Clarke, is trying to reinvigorate its UK business, which has been losing ground to rivals for several years. Kantar retail analyst Bryan Roberts said the brand "was long overdue a facelift" but the revamp was not "bursting with originality" as it was similar to both Morrisons' M Saver brand and Waitrose Essentials.

webTitle: Reed Elsevier sells Totaljobs to Axel Springer

fields.standfirst: Anglo-Dutch publishing and events group confirms €132m deal for UK employment website Totaljobs with German media owner
fields.body:
Reed Elsevier, the Anglo-Dutch publishing and events group, has sold employment website Totaljobs to Axel Springer for £110m.

Axel Springer, which owns Germany's biggest selling newspaper in tabloid Bild, has acquired Totaljobs Group for €132m (£110m).

The deal has been struck by StepStone, Springer's European jobs website, which said that Londonbased Totaljobs Group is the biggest online recruitment business in the UK.

Jens Müffelmann, head of electronic media at Axel Springer, said that the deal makes the German company the "clear number one" in the British online job portal market.

"The Totaljobs Group is an excellently managed and profitable online company … the acquisition is an important milestone in the company's history."

Reed Elsevier is transitioning its operation away from advertising-reliant businesses.

"Reed Business Information is increasingly focused on paid content and data services," said Mark Kelsey, chief executive of RBI. "To compete in an increasingly global market and fully achieve [TotalJob's] future potential [it] will benefit from the scale, focus and international coverage that StepStone brings".

RBI is also home to 100 trade magazines including Farmers Weekly and Flight International. It recently put US show business magazine Variety up for sale. Its Australian magazine operation is also up for sale.

Reed Elsevier put the RBI division up for sale in 2008, but pulled the deal when the recession hit.

In early March Axel Springer partnered with General Atlantic to "create the conditions necessary for a growth offensive in the area of digital classifieds". The two companies have launched Axel Springer Digital Classifieds, in which Axel Springer holds a 70% stake, which will be the home of businesses such as StepStone and Totaljobs.com.

Totaljobs Group was founded in 1999 and employs 340 staff and operates seven job boards.

webTitle: Ryanair hit by new EU inquiry

fields.standfirst: Budget airline faces European commission investigation of its arrangements with Carcassonne airport in southern France
fields.body:
The European commission has opened another flank in hostilities with Ryanair by announcing an investigation of the financial arrangements between the budget airline and Carcassonne airport in France.

The inquiry follows similar scrutiny of affairs at a number of other European airports dealing with Ryanair and other low-cost airlines. The investigations are looking at whether subsidies given to the airports and marketing agreements with airlines breach EU rules on state aid.

Carcassonne airport, owned by the Languedoc-Roussillon region, served just under 400,000 passengers in 2010, virtually all Ryanair's. The commission says it "has doubts" whether public subsidies of at least €11m (£9.1m) between 2000 and 2010 for infrastructure projects at the airport were necessary and proportionate. Another €8m was given for operational activities. Meanwhile, the commission said, the airport gave Ryanair marketing support and discounts that "could give the airline an undue economic advantage".

Ryanair has in the past withdrawn services from a French regional airport, Angoulême, when local authorities refused to continue subsidies.

The commission has recently also opened investigations into arrangements between Ryanair and airports in Germany and Austria.

In 2004 it ordered Ryanair to repay funds from Belgian authorities to land planes at Charleroi airport – a ruling overturned four years later.

Ryanair has issued a series of statements querying the EU's investigations and rulings, as well as contrasting merger permissions, such as the British Airways acquisition of BMI, with its own thwarted takeover of Aer Lingus.

Ryanair spokesman Stephen McNamara said: "While the commission repeatedly ignores state aid to flag carriers, it is currently investigating 17 different Ryanair airport agreements despite the fact that the European court (in 2008) dismissed the commission's claims of state aid in the Charleroi case."

He added: "Ryanair's arrangements with all EU airports comply with competition rules. This latest commission goose-chase is hard to understand when at the same time it bans its bureaucrats from using low-fare airlines or even travelling to Charleroi airport."

webTitle: Petrol panic - now for the good news

fields.bodyText: The fuel tanker dispute has been lambasted by business leaders as threatening a fragile recovery in the UK. But perhaps there is some - albeit short and sharp - economic upside after all. It appears the rush to the petrol pumps by panicked motorists has delivered a big boost to consumer spending. UK spending rose 0.4% in March on the month and 0.3 percentage points of that increase was as a result of spending at petrol pumps, according to the latest Visa Europe UK Expenditure Index compiled with data specialists Markit. Steve Perry, commercial director at Visa Europe commented: "Last week's petrol panic had a tangible impact on overall consumer spending in March as drivers sought to stockpile fuel ... Unadjusted domestic Visa card spending at UK service stations was up 22.7% in March compared against February. It is a rare occurrence when one consumer trend has such a sizeable effect on overall spending and it highlights the scale of the spending that took place in the last few days of the month." But before anyone gets too excited, even with the petrol panic, the underlying trend in consumer spending remains subdued. Economists will also be quick to point out that last week's fuel rush is unlikely to have constituted a net boost to overall spending given it was simply people moving the timing of a purchase they would probably eventually make anyway. Also, any extra money spent on fuel took away from household budgets for spending on other items. The Visa Europe index, based on card transactions that account for £1 in £3 of all UK spending, still shows spending fell 1.7% in annual terms in March. The three-month on three-month trend improved, but remained negative at -0.4% compared with -1.2% in February. So for anyone looking at the official retail sales data due out on 20 April, to get a true picture of spending it will be more important than ever to look at the measures that exclude automotive fuel.

webTitle: FSA arrests 23-year-old City trader

fields.standfirst: Alex Hope, self-proclaimed currency trading 'expert', arrested by City regulators investigating suspected unauthorised trading
fields.body:
A 23-year-old self-proclaimed currency trading expert who received a wave of publicity after reportedly spending £125,000 on a single bottle of champagne, has been arrested by City regulators investigating suspected unauthorised trading.

Alex Hope, formerly a Wembley stadium catering manager, has sought considerable publicity, setting up his own website – alexhopefx.com – and making a number of media appearances.

The Financial Services Authority (FSA) said a 23-year-old had been arrested on suspicion of committing offences under the FSA Markets Act 2000 and the Fraud Act 2006. No one has been charged with an offence.

Hope, who was at his flat in east London's Docklands with friends and family, refused to comment on the reports of his arrest. "I can't talk," he said. "I've got no comment whatsoever, to be honest with you ... I don't want to comment on anything."

Hope, who claims a typical working day for him stretches from 7am until midnight, generated much publicity last month after reputedly spending more than £200,000 on Britain's most expensive round of drinks at a Liverpool nightclub. He is said to have spent £125,000 on a 99lb double Nebuchadnezzar bottle of Armand de Brignac champagne as well as further bottles of champagne and vodka.

In the same week, Hope financed the inaugural Fast Growth Entrepreneurs Club networking event at the Westbury Gallery in Mayfair, London. The London Stock Exchange authorised the use of its name as a sponsor of the event, attended by about 60 entrepreneurs and investors, but is understood not to have provided funding.

In a video interview at the event, featured on Hope's blog, he said: "How I got started in foreign exchange markets was I read a book called Profiting with Forex and also another book How to Get Started in Currency Trading – this was the age of 19 on my journey to work for my old job."

Hope said he studied sports science at university and was barred from switching to economics because he did not have an A-level in maths. Undeterred, he taught himself. "In two to three months, I managed to teach myself what I would have learnt from a three-year course," he said.

Hope has created his own YouTube showreel in which he says: "You don't see a lot of people my age in the City doing what I do. And I feel I have got a lot of good opinions of the markets which you don't hear from people my age."

He featured prominently in a sponsored supplement about spread-betting in the Daily Telegraph last May. "Who would have thought I would become a trader in the City? Certainly not me," he told the paper. "In a year or two, I'd like to set up my own mini hedge fund."

Hope said that before discovering his interest in currency trading, he earned £21,000 a year working in catering management at Wembley stadium. He claims to have briefly worked "as an FX and commodity trader" for the Forex Academy, a Slough-based website that provides courses in currency trading. Last year, he said he had taught "nearly 100" of his friends the elements of currency trading.

Several companies have been aggressively advertising foreign exchange trading books and courses in recent years, making bold claims about the opportunities on offer in some of the most high-risk financial markets. Offering tuition for a fee, rather than managing other peoples money, is not an activity regulated by the FSA.

On Tuesday, regulators and City of London police officers searched an address in east London "in connection with an investigation into a suspected unauthorised foreign exchange trading scheme."

Hope last year set up a company called Short Sterling Limited. He and the company's registrars, Caterham-based AML Benson, are the only directors and no accounts have been filed. He gives his address as a block of flats close to the ExCel Centre by Victoria Dock in east London. According to Land Registry filings, he is not the owner of the lease on that flat.

There is only one Alexander Hope on the FSA's authorised persons register – a 48-year-old independent financial adviser in Gloucester, with no connection to the Hope believed to be at the centre of the FSA's inquiries.

It is not illegal to deal on the foreign exchange markets without FSA authorisation. However, there are circumstances where traders investing other people's funds are required to be registered with and overseen by the regulator. In a recent interview, Hope said: "I use my own money not other people's."

Asked for his top tip for investors hoping to make the most out of currency trading, he said: "Sell the euro and buy safe haven currencies (US dollar, Japanese yen, Swiss franc)."

webTitle: Strong UK services sector survey boosts recovery hopes

fields.bodyText: A spring revival for British businesses has bolstered hopes that the economy is picking up and overcoming the troubles engulfing the eurozone. The latest in a clutch of business surveys to beat expectations indicated that the UK's dominant services sector, which includes hairdressers, banks and transport, enjoyed a jump in activity in March. webTitle: JP Morgan Chase fined $20m for mishandling Lehman Brothers funds

fields.standfirst: Government investigation finds Wall Street giant acted improperly ahead of Lehman's collapse in 2008
fields.body:
JP Morgan Chase is to pay $20m to settle claims that it mishandled customer funds from Lehman Brothers, the bank whose collapse heralded the start of the financial crisis that began in 2008.

The fine is the first for a Wall Street firm related to the collapse of Lehman, the largest bankruptcy in US history. JP Morgan was a major lender to Lehman and has been under scrutiny since Lehman's dramatic collapse on 15 September 2008. Lehman's creditors have accused JP Morgan of siphoning off billions from the fallen bank in the days before it declared bankruptcy.

In other charges, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) said JP Morgan "improperly" held onto funds belonging to Lehman's clients after the bank went bust.

According to the regulator, JP Morgan held on to about $333m of Lehman's customers' money for two weeks after Lehman failed, finally releasing the funds on 30 September 2008. Under CFTC rules, a customer's money should be accessible at any time and should not be considered as assets.

JP Morgan was also accused of using the funds of Lehman's clients in its calculations about how much money to lend to Lehman. As the funds belong to the client – and not the bank – such a calculation is a violation of federal law. The calculation allowed JP Morgan to lend more money to troubled Lehman as it careened toward disaster.

David Meister, director of the CFTC's division of enforcement, said: "The laws applying to customer segregated accounts impose critical restrictions on how financial institutions can treat customer funds, and prohibit these institutions from standing in the way of immediate withdrawal.

"As should be crystal clear, these laws must be strictly observed at all times, whether the markets are calm or in crisis."

In a statement, JP Morgan said: "No customer funds were ever used to satisfy any LBI [Lehman Brothers Inc] debt to JPMorgan, nor were any customer funds in these accounts lost. The CFTC does not claim that JPMorgan Chase intentionally violated the Commodity Exchange Act or CFTC regulations."

Lehman's creditors subpoenaed treasury secretary Timothy Geithner this year as they pursued JP Morgan for the money they allege the bank owes them. Geithner was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at the time of Lehman's collapse and was intimately involved in the decision to let the bank fail rather than bail it out.

The creditors allege that Jamie Dimon, JP Morgan's chief executive, and other top bank executives used inside knowledge to take advantage of Lehman as it teetered on the edge of collapse.

JP Morgan has strenuously denied any wrongdoing. JP Morgan and Bank of New York Mellon process most transactions for Wall Street's top firms and are therefore often in the thick of the action when things go wrong.

As Lehman's woes mounted in 2008, JP Morgan asked the bank to put up more than $8bn in collateral in order to continue trading. JP Morgan's demands put more pressure on Lehman and may have expedited its collapse.

Anton Valukas, the lawyer who was appointed to investigate Lehman's collapse, found that Lehman had been insolvent for weeks before it filed for bankruptcy. He said the bank's executives had used a series of complicated transactions to hide its true liabilities.

Valukas concluded that Lehman boss Dick Fuld was "at least grossly negligent". But he also concluded that JP Morgan and Citigroup contributed to Lehman's demise by demanding more collateral and changing guarantee agreements as the bank struggled with its debts and evaporating investor confidence.

The fine comes as the CFTC and other US regulators are investigating similar charges at MF Global, the derivatives broker that declared bankruptcy last year. The collapse revealed a $1.6bn shortfall in customer funds.

webTitle: FTSE 100 drops 2% on eurozone woes, while Next slides as Lord Wolfson sells £3.8m worth of shares

fields.standfirst: Leading index records biggest daily fall since last November and hits lowest level since January as Spanish bond sales disappoints
fields.body:
As markets headed south for the second day running and the FTSE 100 turned in its worst daily performance in more than four months, Next was one of the day's major fallers following a £3.8m share sale by its chief executive.

On Tuesday, the same day Lord Wolfson unveiled the shortlist for his economics prize, he was also authorising the sale of 125,000 shares at £30.57. Other investors decided to follow suit, and Next shares lost 123p to £29.37. Simon Irwin at Liberum Capital said:

Simon Wolfson...doesn't appear to sell shares very often. According to Bloomberg the last two occasions were just before the shares peaked in 2007 and in 2004. It goes along with the rather more cautious approach taken by the company of late, particularly when they effectively cut the guidance on current year buybacks from £200m to £140m-£200m. Wolfson is publicly very bearish on the euro and the damage that it can do to the UK, but he has read the macro extremely well in the past and he has also traded his own shares equally well. Although the shares have lagged the sector year to date and over the past 6 months, we think there are macro risks for the UK retailers and company specific for Next's margins which are not discounted and would be strongly tempted to follow Wolfson's lead and sell.

There was little cheer elsewhere. The market was under pressure from the start following overnight hints from the US Federal Reserve that it may not be planning further measures to stimulate the country's economy. But the falls really accelerated following a poorly received Spanish bond auction, which only went to emphasise its current financial stress. A monthly US service sector survey proved a slight disappointment, and even better than expected American jobs figures - an ADP report showed a 209,000 rise in March compared to a 206,000 forecast - failed to halt the slide.

So the FTSE 100 finished 134.57 points lower at 5703.77, its worst daily performance since 21 November last year and its lowest level since 31 January.

Mining and banking shares - the usual victims when investors shy away from risk - lost ground. Fresnillo, the Mexican precious metals miner, fell 138p to £15.33 as silver and gold prices dropped.

But that did not stop some takeover speculation in the sector, with talk that Rio Tinto, Glencore and possibly a Chinese company may be looking at First Quantum Minerals, down 39p at £11.51. Canada's First Quantum recently settled a dispute with Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation over a disputed project in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

Among the banks, Barclays lost 11.85p to 218.5p and Royal Bank of Scotland fell 0.79p to 26.1p.

Shares in pharmaceuticals group Shire bucked the trend for much of the day before finally capitulating to the sell-off.

The company has seen a number of setbacks in the past few weeks, including a failed clinical study relating to its Lialda treatment and the withdrawal of a regulatory application for its drug for Fabry disease.

Its shares ended 5p lower at £20.25 despite Morgan Stanley repeating its overweight rating (although the bank cut its target price from £25.80 to £24.30). Analyst Peter Verdult said:

We continue to believe Shire is one of the best positioned companies across pharma, underpinned by its exposure to the fast growing therapeutic categories of ADHD, orphan drugs and diabetes. Despite recent disappointments, we still forecast a 2012-15 earnings per share compound annual growth rate of 17%, with our 2015 forecast 14% ahead of consensus.
We believe the market continues to under-appreciate the global potential of Shire's ADHD franchise as well as label expansion opportunities for Vyvanse. Efforts to strengthen the pipeline continue and we note Shire's financial strength: net debt below $0.5bn with free cash flow of more than $1.0bn per annum.

Elsewhere International Power edged 0.8p lower to 402.2p after the company rejected a takeover bid by its majority owner GDF Suez.

France's GDF made an offer last week to buy the remaining 30% of International Power it does not already own. It said it would pay 390p a share in cash, valuing its target at £19.9bn.

But this was only marginally above the market price and the City and investors labelled the offer as too stingy. Now International Power's independent directors - whose approval GDF needs ahead of an August lock-up arrangement - have agreed. They said:

The members of the independent committee have unanimously concluded the indicative proposal....undervalues International Power and accordingly GDF has been notified [we are] unable to accept [it].

GDF responded that it believed its offer was attractive, and said it would continue to consider its options following the rejection of the proposal. This could include withdrawing the offer.

Among the mid-caps, engineering group Kentz Corporation, which services the oil industry, dropped 35.2p to 437.8p after two of its largest shareholders, non-executives Tan Sri Mohd Razali Abdul Rahman and Hassan Abas, sold 15m shares = a 12.89% stake - held by their Kerbet company at 430p each. Kerbet now holds 13.64% and Rahman - who is also chairman of Kentz - said the sale was designed to diversify its portfolio. Kentz said the size of the share placing was increased from 12m after strong institutional demand.

Finally could Resolution, which last year took a tilt at fellow insurer Phoenix, return to the fray? With Phoenix shares down 22p at 545.5p it seems the market thinks it unlikely. But analyst James Pearce at UBS believed it would be a better idea for Resolution than its recently proposed split:

We think management could add more value by reviving the talks with Phoenix. We estimate an all stock offer worth 700p per Phoenix share (a 25% premium) would be 24%-37% earnings enhancing for Resolution. It would also give them an asset manager, and create a stronger base from which to renegotiate Phoenix's debt. However, Resolution and Phoenix both say the talks are off.

Pearce cut his rating on Resolution shares - down 6p at 253p - from buy to neutral, and his price target from 300p to 250p.

webTitle: Why the golden era for overseas aid is over - for now | Larry Elliott

fields.bodyText: It hardly comes as a massive shock that flows of aid were down last year. No western country has been left unscathed by the downturn of the past five years and that financial pressure is reflected in the development assistance figures released by the Paris-based Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Cuts to aid budgets in Spain and Greece - two countries where the belt-tightening has been severe - were of the order of 40%, but countries that have weathered the storm more easily were also less generous last year. Austria cut its aid budget by more than 14%, France by 5.6% and there was even a small reduction of 0.8% in UK financial assistance. The big picture was that aid flows fell by $3.4bn (£2.14bn) in real (inflation-adjusted terms) to $133bn in 2011. According to Oxfam, once exceptional factors such as the timing of debt relief are stripped out, it was the first fall in development assistance since 1997. What do the figures tell us? In terms of the UK, not all that much. The government is still on course to hit its target of increasing aid to 0.7% of national income by 2013: the intention was always to have a big jump in assistance between 2012 and 2013. Globally, however, the OECD data does suggest that the golden era for aid is now over, for the time being at least. Pledges made at Gleneagles in 2005, when the economic outlook was benign and western countries were flush - have not been met. The financial climate is now a lot more hostile, and politicians in rich countries are finding it hard to justify spending more on poor people in poor countries when they are cutting spending on poor people at home. Apart from the budgetary pressures, there are a number of reasons why western donors are making less of an effort than they were in the middle of the last decade. One is the sense that parts of the developing world are doing fine and therefore don't need the help they once did. This is a pretty shallow argument, since what applies to China does not apply to the poorer countries of sub-Saharan Africa, which have enormous physical and human infrastructure needs. A second reason is that there is no individual or government in the west that is pushing the aid agenda in the way that Gordon Brown and Tony Blair once did. Finally, it has to be said that the fizz has gone out of the anti-poverty campaign groups. They were making a big fuss today when the OECD aid figures came out, but need to have a look at their own performance, which in recent years has been distinctly lacklustre. Even in the good years, politicians had to be pushed into action, and this was nearly always the result of public demands for change orchestrated by development groups. Until the spirit and the energy that led to Jubilee 2000 and Make Poverty History is rekindled, western politicians will be able to get away with breaking their promises.

fields.standfirst: Downbeat comments from European Central Bank and overnight statement from US Federal Reserve hit shares
fields.body:
Global stock markets are continuing to slide as downbeat comments from the European Central Bank and a slightly disappointing US service sector figure have added to earlier concerns.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is now down more than 160 points - a 1.2% decline - while the FTSE 100 is off 113.33 points at 5725.01. Only Shire, up 13p at £20.34 after a positive Morgan Stanley note, is in positive territory in the leading index.

France's Cac and Germany's Dax are both down around 2.3%. At the regular ECB press conference, its president Mario Draghi said there were still risks to the outlook for the European economy from the financial crisis and rising commodity prices.

Meanwhile the Institute for Supply Management said its US service sector index had fallen to 56 in March from 57.3 in February, and lower than the expected 57 reading.

Markets have been under pressure all day, following poor Australian export figures and hints from the US Federal Reserve there may not be any more measures such as quantitative easing to boost the world's largest economy. Last week the Fed's Ben Bernanke seemed to suggest the opposite, that more stimulus was on the cards.

The falls really accelerated, however, after a poor Spanish bond auction, the first since the country's austerity budget was announced amid a general strike.

webTitle: Developing countries deserve a greater say in World Bank governance | Joseph Stiglitz

fields.standfirst: Should America continue to insist on controlling the selection process, it is the World Bank itself that would suffer
fields.body:
Barack Obama's nomination of Jim Yong Kim for the presidency of the World Bank has been well received – and rightly so, especially given some of the other names that were bandied about. In Kim, a public health professor who is now president of Dartmouth University and previously led the World Health Organization's HIV/AIDS department, the United States has put forward a good candidate. But the candidate's nationality, and the nominating country – whether small and poor or large and rich – should play no role in determining who gets the job.

The World Bank's 11 executive directors from emerging and developing countries have put forward two excellent candidates, Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala of Nigeria and José Antonio Ocampo of Colombia. I have worked closely with both of them. Both are first-rate, have served as ministers with multiple portfolios, have performed admirably in top positions in multilateral organizations, and have the diplomatic skills and professional competence to do an outstanding job. They understand finance and economics, the bread and butter of the World Bank, and have a network of connections to leverage the Bank's effectiveness.

Okonjo-Iweala brings an insider's knowledge of the institution. Ocampo, like Kim, brings the advantages and disadvantages of being an outsider; but Ocampo, a distinguished professor at Columbia University, is thoroughly acquainted with the World Bank. He previously served not only as minister of economics and finance, but also of agriculture – a critically important qualification, given that the vast majority of the developing countries' poor depend on farming. He also brings impressive environmental credentials, addressing another of the Bank's central concerns.

Both Okonjo-Iweala and Ocampo understand the role of international financial institutions in providing global public goods. Throughout their careers, their hearts and minds have been devoted to development, and to fulfilling the World Bank's mission of eliminating poverty. They have set a high bar for any American candidate.

Much is at stake. Almost two billion people remain in poverty in the developing world, and, while the World Bank cannot solve the problem on its own, it plays a leading role. Despite its name, the Bank is primarily an international development institution. Kim's speciality, public health, is critical, and the Bank has long supported innovative initiatives in this field. But health is only a small part of the Bank's "portfolio," and it typically works in this area with partners who bring to the table expertise in medicine.

Rumours suggest that the US is likely to insist on maintaining the perverse selection process in which it gets to pick the World Bank's president, simply because, in this election year, Obama's opponents would trumpet loss of control over the choice as a sign of weakness. And it is more important for the US to retain that control than it is for emerging and developing countries to obtain it.

Indeed, the more powerful of the emerging markets know how to live within the current system, and they may use it to their advantage. They will, in effect, obtain an IOU, to be cashed in for something that is more important. The realpolitik of the moment makes fighting over the presidency unlikely; America may well prevail. But at what cost?

Should America continue to insist on controlling the selection process, it is the Bank itself that would suffer. For years, the Bank's effectiveness was compromised because it was seen, in part, as a tool of western governments and their countries' financial and corporate sectors. Ironically, even America's long-term interests would be best served by a commitment – not just in words, but also in deeds – to a merit-based system and good governance.

One supposed achievement of the G20 was an agreement to reform the governance of the international financial institutions – most importantly, how their leaders are selected. Since expertise on development by and large lies within the emerging and developing countries – after all, they live development – it seems natural that the World Bank's head would come from one of those countries. To maintain a cabal among developed countries, whereby the US appoints the World Bank president and Europe picks the International Monetary Fund's head, seems particularly anachronistic and perplexing today, when the Bank and the Fund are turning to emerging market countries as a source of funds.

While the US, the international community, and the Bank itself repeatedly emphasise the importance of good governance, a selection procedure that de facto leaves the appointment to the US president makes a mockery of it.

Okonjo-Iweala put the matter forcefully in an interview with the Financial Times: what is at stake is a matter of hypocrisy. The integrity of the advanced industrial countries, which have a majority of the votes at the World Bank, is being put to the test.

webTitle: Essar Energy sees tax ruling appeal disallowed by India's supreme court

fields.standfirst: Power company's shares lost nearly 4% on ruling over repayment of sales tax
fields.body:
Essar Energy has seen its appeal against an Indian tax ruling disallowed by the country's supreme court.

In January the company lost out in relation to a scheme whereby it had been able to defer the repayment of sales tax. So far it has benefited to the tune of $1.24bn, but this looks like it will now come to an end. The company - 77% owned by Indian conglomerate Essar - was originally due to repay the tax from 2021 onwards, but the ruling meant it was unclear when the payments will now start.

Essar has now said its review petition has been disallowed, but it added it had already recognised the liability in its accounts and was in talks about finalising repayment of the liabilities. It is also in discussions with banks about meeting the repayment obligations.

The news has sent Essar - which was ejected from the FTSE 100 at the most recent quarterly index review - down 6.1p to 154.6p.

webTitle: Healthcare group BTG climbs 2% after raising full year guidance

fields.standfirst: Company says its licensing and biotech business boosted by higher than expected royalties
fields.body:
BTG, the healthcare group, has added around 2% in a down market after a positive trading update.

The company said trading in its licensing and biotechnology businesses had been significantly ahead of expectations, driven by higher than expected royalties from haemophilia treatment BeneFIX and prostate cancer drug Zytiga.

So BTG has raised its estimated revenues for the year from £160m-£165m to £190m-£195m. The company is also hoping to launch Varisolve, its varicose veins treatment, in the US before long after the first of two trials met its targets. BTG shares are up 7.6p at 345.9p, and analysts at Jefferies issued a buy note and raised their price target from 345p to 410p. But there were differing views elsewhere in the City. Dr Paul Cuddon at Peel Hunt said:

Further extensions to BeneFIX royalties, milestones/royalties on Zytiga and a strong performance from CroFab in the US has led to significant upgrades to 2012 revenue forecasts, which equates to £52m in earnings from £32m. We still remain cautious over the outlook for the rest of 2012.

And Justin Smith at Oriel Securities issues a sell note, dismissing suggestions the company could be a takeover target:

We like BTG's strategy of focusing on those therapeutic areas with high unmet need and high barriers. However, despite today's news, in our view the medium term consensus earnings per share forecasts still discount far too optimistic a scenario for both the company's transition to direct selling in the US and the launch of Varisolve (removes varicose veins).
In addition, in forecasting that the company attains industry ceiling earnings margins in just five years time we believe that consensus is being too optimistic on the potential operational leverage which BTG can deliver. Also, given that the current share price already discounts 20 years of future cash flow, in our view valuation leaves no room for error. We acknowledge that the bulls argue that a key upside to risk to the share price is a potential acquisition of BTG. However, in our view such a deal is unlikely for two reasons: (i) the high level of earnings uncertainty associated with the event risk on Varisolve (ii) BTG's business mix (ie part Pharma, part MedTech) tempers the strategic rationale for the acquirer.

webTitle: Shire backed by broker despite recent disappointments, but FTSE 100 slide continues

fields.standfirst: Morgan Stanley positive on pharmaceuticals group, but poor Spanish bond auction sends leading shares lower
fields.body:
Leading shares are sliding following a poorly received Spanish bond auction, but pharmaceuticals group Shire is bucking the trend.

The company has seen a number of setbacks in the past few weeks, including a failed clinical study relating to its Lialda treatment and the withdrawal of a regulatory application for its drug for Fabry disease.

But its shares are currently 27p higher at £20.57, the biggest riser in a falling FTSE 100 after Morgan Stanley repeated its overweight rating although the bank cut its target price from £25.80 to £24.30. Analyst Peter Verdult said:

We continue to believe Shire is one of the best positioned companies across pharma, underpinned by its exposure to
the fast growing therapeutic categories of ADHD, orphan drugs and diabetes. Despite recent disappointments, we still forecast a 2012-15 earnings per share compound annual growth rate of 17%, with our 2015 forecast 14% ahead of consensus. We believe the market continues to under-appreciate the global potential of Shire's ADHD franchise as well as label expansion opportunities for Vyvanse. Efforts to strengthen the pipeline continue and we note Shire's financial strength: net debt below $0.5bn with free cash flow of more than $1.0bn per annum.

Other drug companies are also in demand for their defensive qualities in a falling market, with GlaxoSmithKline up 8.5p at £14.37.

The market sell-off - which was initially caused by poor Australian export figures and hints the US Federal Reserve may not authorise further quantitative easing - has accelerated following the bond auction. Spain raised less than hoped at a higher than expected interest rate. So the FTSE 100 is now down 64.68 points at 5773.66, with French and German markets both down more than 1%.

webTitle: International Power dips as it rejects GDF bid while Next falls on Wolfson £3.8m share sale

fields.standfirst: UK power group says offer by majority French owner undervalues the business while GDF says considering options
fields.body:
International Power shares have dipped after the company rejected a takeover bid by its majority owner GDF Suez.

France's GDF - in one of the least unexpected moves in recent corporate history - made an offer last week to buy the remaining 30% of International Power it does not already own. It said it would pay 390p a share in cash, valuing its target at £19.9bn.

But this was only marginally above the market price and the City and investors labelled the offer as too stingy. Now International Power's independent directors - whose approval GDF needs ahead of an August lock-up arrangement - have agreed. They said:

The members of the independent committee have unanimously concluded the indicative proposal....undervalues International Power and accordingly GDF has been notified [we are] unable to accept [it].
Under the terms of the relationship agreement.. GDF and its affiliates are generally restricted from making a takeover offer for [International Power] for the period until 3 August 2012 (or earlier with the consent of all of the independent non-executive directors.

GDF has responded that it believed its offer was attractive, and said it would continue to consider its options following the rejection of the proposal. This could include withdrawing the offer:

Any decision by the group will be based on a strict disciplined and value-driven approach to earnings, indebtedness and returns.

In the market International Power's shares are down 0.5p at 402.5p - still well above the offer price - and investors await further developments. Guillaume Redgwell at Liberum Capital said:

This is not a major surprise - the shares have been trading above the indicative offer since the original announcement.

Overall the market has fallen back once again, with the damage done by news of disappointing Australian exports, mixed service sector surveys and, notably, hints from the US Federal Reserve that it may not implement any further boosts to the economy such as quantitative easing.

The FTSE 100 is down 32.09 points at 5806.25, with mining groups among the major fallers. Fresnillo is down 66p at £16.05 and Rio Tinto is 67.5p lower at £34.63.

Retailers are under pressure, with Next down 83p at £29.77 as Lord Wolfson - on the same day as he unveiled the shortlist for his economics prize - raised £3.8m by selling 125,000 shares at £30.57. Simon Irwin at Liberum Capital said:

Simon Wolfson...doesn't appear to sell shares very often. According to Bloomberg the last two occasions were just before the shares peaked in 2007 and in 2004. It goes along with the rather more cautious approach taken by the company of late, particularly when they effectively cut the guidance on current year buybacks from £200m to £140m-£200m. Wolfson is publicly very bearish on the euro and the damage that it can do to the UK, but he has read the macro extremely well in the past and he has also traded his own shares equally well. Although the shares have lagged the sector year to date and over the past 6 months, we think there are macro risks for the UK retailers and company specific for Next's margins which are not discounted and would be strongly tempted to follow Wolfson's lead and sell.
